review.title: Clustering and Bayesian network for image of faces classification
review.abstract: In a content based image classification system, target images are sorted by feature similarities with respect to the query (CBIR). In this paper, we propose to use new approach combining distance tangent, k-means algorithm and Bayesian network for image classification. First, we use the technique of tangent distance to calculate several tangent spaces representing the same image. The objective is to reduce the error in the classification phase. Second, we cut the image in a whole of blocks. For each block, we compute a vector of descriptors. Then, we use K-means to cluster the low-level features including color and texture information to build a vector of labels for each image. Finally, we apply five variants of Bayesian networks classifiers (Na\"ive Bayes, Global Tree Augmented Na\"ive Bayes (GTAN), Global Forest Augmented Na\"ive Bayes (GFAN), Tree Augmented Na\"ive Bayes for each class (TAN), and Forest Augmented Na\"ive Bayes for each class (FAN) to classify the image of faces using the vector of labels. In order to validate the feasibility and effectively, we compare the results of GFAN to FAN and to the others classifiers (NB, GTAN, TAN). The results demonstrate FAN outperforms than GFAN, NB, GTAN and TAN in the overall classification accuracy.

metadata.title: Clustering and Bayesian network for image of faces classification

sections.text: This year, it has reached the stage where it will be able to put itself at the forefront in order to pave the way for the future.

sections.heading: A. Definition
sections.text: Bayesian networks represent a series of variables in the form of nodes on a directed acyclic graph. It maps the conditional dependencies of these variables. Bayesian networks bring us four advantages as a data modeling tool [20-22-24]. First, Bayesian networks are able to process incomplete or noisy data, which is very common in image analysis. Second, Bayesian networks are able to determine causal relationships by conditional dependencies, which allows for modeling relationships between variables. Finally, Bayesian networks are able to incorporate existing knowledge or already known data into their learning and provide more accurate results by using what we already know. Bayesian networks are defined by: A directed acyclic graph (DAG) G = (V, E), where V is a set of nodes of G, and E of G is the computational ability of G; a probable space B.

sections.heading: C. Parameters learning
sections.text: In this case, the structure is a priori fully known and all variables can be observed from the data. Learning conditional probabilities associated with variables (network nodes) can be done either randomly or using a Bayesian approach. Statistical learning requirements in the training data are based on the Maximum Probability (ML), which is defined as follows: Where is the number of events in the database for which the variable in the state of its parents is located in the configurationThe Bayesian approach to learning from complete data is to find the most likely data based on the data observed using the Maximum a Posteriori (MAP) method, where: With the conjugate before distribution; est la distribution de Dirichlet: And the parameter at the back:

sections.heading: D. Structure learning
sections.text: Structure learning is the finding of a plausible structure for a graph based on data input. However, it has been proven that this is a NP-hard problem, and therefore any learning algorithm that would be suitable for use on a data set as large as microarray data requires some form of modification to be feasible. Spirtes et al. (2001) explain that it is a major problem to find the most suitable DAG from sample data, since the number of possible DAGs grows superexponentially with the number of nodes present. The number of possible structures is superexponential in the number of variables. The number of possible combinations G of DAGs from n variables can be calculated by the recursive formula [20] In practice, we use heuristics and approximation methods such as the K2 algorithm.

sections.heading: E. Bayesian network as a classifier
sections.text: 1) Naïve Bayes is one of the most effective and efficient classification algorithms. The assumption of conditional independence in naïve Bayes is rarely true in reality. In fact, naïve Bayes have been shown to work poorly for regression problems (Frank et al., 2000) and produce poor probability estimates (Bennett, 2000). One way to alleviate the assumption of conditional independence is to expand the structure of naïve Bayes so that they explicitly represent dependencies between attributes by adding arcs between attributes. Construct TAN procedures are described in our previous paper [5].3) FANTo improve the performance of TAN, we have added a premature stop criterion based on a minimum value of increasing the score in search algorithms.

sections.text: Our approach is based on modeling the image using a 3x3 grid that reflects a local description of the image. Thus, the image to be processed is treated as a grid of nine blocks (Figure 6). sections.text: The originality of this work is the development of a Bayesian network for each class. Subsequently, we compared the results of this network with a global Bayesian network. We used naive Bayes, Global Structure Tree Augmented Naïve Bayes, Global Structure Forest Augmented Naïve Bayes, Tree Augmented Naïve Bayes for each class (TAN) and Forest Augmented Naïve Bayes for each class (FAN). This subsection describes the implementation of these methods.

We begin by presenting the database with which we conducted our tests, and then present our results according to the structure used (global or one for each class).

sections.heading: A. Data base prensentation
sections.text: Now we present the results of the contribution of our approach to classifying images of some class examples from the used database "Database of Faces." We used the face database of GTAV, which was found at 1, and the face database of ORL (Figure 7), which was used at 2. The databases are used to evaluate the system classification in the presence of facial variations in light conditions, facial expressions (smiling, open / closed eyes) and facial details (glasses / no glasses).

sections.text: For each experiment, we used the percentage of correct classification (PCC) to evaluate classification accuracy as follows: The results of the experiments are summarized in Tables IV, V and Figure 10 with the number of clusters k = 83; Naive Bayes, Global TAN, Global FAN, TAN and FAN use the same training set and are evaluated exactly on the same test set.

sections.heading: E. Naïve Bayes
sections.text: Table III shows that the naive Bayesian networks, despite their simple construction, had a very good classification rate. However, this rate is improving as we see that the classification rate achieved by Class 3 is 40%. We conclude that there is a slight dependence between the 3 The choice of the k-value, which was discussed in our previous paper [5], attributes that must be determined by performing structural learning.

sections.heading: F. Tree augmented Naïve Bayes
sections.text: The table above shows that the rate of correct classification is decreasing, but there is a slight improvement in the rate of correct classification based on a class structure.

sections.heading: G. Forest augmented Naïve Bayes
sections.text: The table above shows that the rate of correct classification of GFAN is the same as that of naïve Bayes. Since learning the GFAN structure with a strict threshold corresponding to 0.8 yielded the same structure as that of naïve Bayes. However, if we use the structure of Class 1, we find that the classification rate has been slightly improved to Class 1. Also for Class 3, the classification rate increased from 0.4 to 0.9 using the structure of Class 3 FAN.

metadata.abstractText: In a content based image classification system, target images are sorted by feature similarities with respect to the query (CBIR). In this paper, we propose to use new approach combining distance tangent, k-means algorithm and Bayesian network for image classification. First, we use the technique of tangent distance to calculate several tangent spaces representing the same image. The objective is to reduce the error in the classification phase. Second, we cut the image in a whole of blocks. For each block, we compute a vector of descriptors. Then, we use K-means to cluster the low-level features including color and texture information to build a vector of labels for each image. Finally, we apply five variants of Bayesian networks classifiers (Naïve Bayes, Global Tree Augmented Naïve Bayes (GTAN), Global Forest Augmented Naïve Bayes (GFAN), Tree Augmented Naïve Bayes for each class (TAN), and Forest Augmented Naïve Bayes for each class (FAN) to classify the image of faces using the vector of labels. In order to validate the feasibility and effectively, we compare the results of GFAN to FAN and to the others classifiers (NB, GTAN, TAN). The results demonstrate FAN outperforms than GFAN, NB, GTAN and TAN in the overall classification accuracy. Keywords; face recognition, clustering, Bayesian network, Naïve Bayes, TAN, FAN
